job_title: Customer Service Representative in Cape Town
pros: Work from home. Medical Aid after completing seasonal work and three month probationary period.
cons:
Toxic corporate work ‘ethos’ - like being brainwashed into a cult. You’ll work overnight and be too exhausted to live a normal life and have no say over your schedule regarding how good your ‘metrics’ are - they mean nothing. Your managers will demean and undermine you. You will be screamed at and berated by customers daily, you will have timed breaks and be reprehended if you go seconds over those breaks. You will be pushed within a team to up your overall team metrics to make your manager look good, and not get any credit for it. You’ll be forced to train and work in departments you don’t enjoy or understand. Your strengths will NEVER be recognized or developed here.

It is amazons business model to make you replaceable and to have a high turn over rate. Jeff Bezos has no interest in his employees. He is an autocratic, money hoarding billionaire, who outsources to country’s who have a poor dollar exchange rate so that he can get away with paying them next to nothing and employ huge amounts of people. You’ll never get paid what you deserve. You’ll never get the recognition you deserve. You will always be treated as disposable.

Don’t drink the kool-aid.

job_title: FC Associate I in Wilmington, OH
pros: Good pay, consistent work, high job security as long as you do your duties. Can leave whenever you want so long as you have enough unpaid time or paid time accumulated.
cons: The shift kinda sucks (5PM-12:15AM and occasionally can flex up to 2 additional hours). They claim to promote from within, but I'd say 70% of the time they will offer leadership positions to people outside the company. HR is nearly impossible to get a hold of sometimes. In my facility it has gotten to the point where HR and management have locked themselves in their office. Had a computer engineering degree and they never showed me a clear path to get into their IT department even though they'd hire people straight out of HS to work in it. Vacation days accumulate very slowly although you always have the option to take an extended leave of absence. Overall not a bad place to work over the summer to make money, but unless you work in the front half of the week, you will never have weekends off. You will often spend most of your days in between work asleep, driving to work, and driving home. Most likely you will only have 2 hours to yourself. If they paid more I would be a much happier employee.

review_title: Developing at a leader and in a winning company, but do expect sacrifices, and frustration of not a lot of reward
pros: Business model and top level vision. Winning and international environment. Strong culture for excellence, analytics, action and results, giving autonomy and material operational responsibilities quickly. High level of systems and processes. Very smart people and engagement levels of the teams. Ability to challenge status quo and constantly re-invent to improve. Learning and self development across all leadership, management and business operational areas. Fast pace and reactivity, capability to quickly correct course of actions to restore performance. International career opportunities (provided individual flexibility, mobility and acceptance of below par compensation though).
cons: Below average compensation in regards of the demands during recruitment process. High workload expected and little work-life balance perks. Management by criticism vs valuation of successes or people efforts. Very centralized leadership in the US and final decision making power on decisions forcing to constantly justify when not working in headquarters. Extremely high friction in promotions, leadership leveling disjoints for similar roles between US and rest of the world. Overall not high consideration for people (expendable resource). High level feelings of frustration and attrition as outcome (people all secretely dream to leave after making enough years on their resume to make a career jump).

review_title: A Great Place to Work! I'm thankful to be here.
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Seattle, WA
pros:
There are a lot of pros to working at Amazon; some of them are:

- A high hiring bar means I'm working with great people that are self motivated and extremely good at what they do.
- Amazon has a lot of great internal learning resources that can improve your skills if you take advantage of them.
- Great compensation and benefits.
- No matter what your role or business area is, you are working on the cutting edge of technology and innovation; it's interesting work. 
- Amazon encourages its employees to move around the company and try different roles in other business areas.
cons: None so far, its been a great experience.

review_title: No reason to come to work here
pros:
If you negotiate well, they'll throw money at you to bring in you in. Cause their reputation is so bad no one wants to come here. 
You'll see how's being in pressure cooker and how to survive if you're amongst sharks ready to bite you every single day. People come to work with a mental sword and shield to survive everyday. 
Company is full of internationals so you'll get diversity, poor guys come here with the carrot of immigration support and then are exploited, hope the department of labor reads this. If they were no tied with visa 80% of internationals I know would have left yesterday.
cons:
Just search for Amazon work culture and read the first 10 links.
The mantra in this company (at least in the Retail, Marketplace and AWS business) is to exploit resources as much as possible, crack whip and treat them like slaves, so either they learn the amazon way of throwing people under the bus and survive by managing up or just leave. 
People Managers are incentivized if they crack whip and get work done not by motivating. If you are type A, love playing the blame game and insensitive animal, perfect place for you

pros:
Decent pay with frequent extra $5/hour incentive days. 
Lots of hand sanitizers, wipes and masks available for employees during these Covid times.
Flexible shifts.
cons:
1) High expectations. They want us to pick more than 100u/hour consistently even though most aisles have 3 other pickers plus stowers and most of the items needed to pick involve a use of ladder which sometimes are not available readily. When you question this, they say they have associates that do it so you can too smh...I really doubt that.
2) They expect us to prep the bags in 5 minutes or less which is close to impossible if you are doing a chill or freezer pick what with adding the liners and all. If you want us to go faster amazon, maybe the quality will go down....no wonder they have been consistently sending messages since past 2 weeks to add liners, I assume people are skipping steps to save time...!
3) The thickest gloves they have are not of good quality to keep your fingers safe in the freezer, even with hand warmers. I would rather take breaks and get out of freezer than getting frost bite, sorry but not sorry I am more concerned of my health than pick rates. 
4) Breaks are timed (they watch you), one 15 minutes break when you work 5 hour shift with additional 5 minutes to walk back (which is like a quarter mile) and start the next task. 
5) Favoritism. They like lazy stupid people and managers prefer them than hardworking people who are doing the job the best they can.
Some managers think associates are stupid and think being sarcastic is kind of funny and make them seem cool. I don't care how big a manager you are, you respect me then I respect you...they forget some people woking there are only doing so because of being laid off due to covid and have more degrees and may I daresay better suited to do their jobs!!!
6) They hire anybody if background check seem okay I think, but I tell you some people working there are absolutely crazy! They should do a filter process from the application pool somehow.

review_title: Good team but barely any instruction or training.
pros:
Well, it's a job if you need one.

Pay is decent in some areas.
cons: - There wasn't any true training except a few short videos at the first meeting after getting hired. When you start we were told what to do (dock, inducting, picking, or sorting), after that it's up to you to either ask for advice or to watch other's as they do the task. This is where a good team environment is key. Although due to how Amazon continuously tracks your performance, many don't have the time to explain things to you.
